revision.comment: /* Major breed families of fancy pigeon */ simplify heading
revision.text:
'''Fancy pigeons''' are a type of [[domestic pigeon]]s, which are [[Domestication|domesticated]] varieties of the wild [[rock dove]] (''Columba livia''). They are bred by [[Pigeon keeping|pigeon fanciers]] for various traits relating to size, shape, color, and behavior,<ref name="Levi">{{cite book |last=Levi |first=Wendell |title= The Pigeon|year= 1977|publisher= Levi Publishing Co, Inc|location= Sumter, South Carolina|isbn=0-85390-013-2 }}</ref> who often exhibit their birds at pigeon shows, fairs and other [[Livestock show|livestock exhibits]].<ref>{{cite book| last =Blechman | first =Andrew | title =Pigeons-The fascinating saga of the world's most revered and reviled bird. | publisher =University of Queensland Press | year =2007 | location =St Lucia, Queensland | url =http://www.uqp.uq.edu.au/book_details.php?isbn=9780702236419| isbn =978-0-7022-3641-9 }}</ref>
There are about 800 pigeon breeds; considering all regional varieties all over the world there may be 1100 breeds.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Schütte |first1=Joachim |title=Handbuch der Taubenrassen |url= |year=1971 |publisher=Neumann-Neudamm |location=Melsungen, Berlin, Basel, Wien |language=de |isbn=9783788800116 |oclc=74047160 |chapter=EINLEITUNG |chapterurl=//russiastation.tripod.com/Handbuch/1.htm}}</ref> The European list of fancy pigeons alone names about 500 breeds.<ref>{{cite web|title=EE-list of fancy pigeons (ELFP)|url=http://www.entente-ee.com/deutsch/sparten/tauben/Dateien/2012/ELRT%2011-06-2012.pdf|publisher=Entente Européenne d’Aviculture et de Cuniculture|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130415154727/http://www.entente-ee.com/deutsch/sparten/tauben/Dateien/2012/ELRT%2011-06-2012.pdf|archivedate=2013-04-15|df=}}</ref> No other domestic animal has branched out into such a variety of forms and colours.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Lyell |first1=James C. |title=Fancy Pigeons |url=//archive.org/details/fancypigeons00lyelgoog |year=1881 |publisher=Barnes & Noble |location=London |oclc=8005808}}</ref>
[[Charles Darwin]] is known to have crossbred fancy pigeons, particularly the [[Ice Pigeon]], to study variation within species,<ref>{{cite web|last=Ross|first=John|title=Darwin's Pigeons|url=http://darwinspigeons.com/}}</ref> this work coming three years before his groundbreaking publication, ''[[On the Origin of Species]]''.
==Pigeon showing== [[File:Philoperisteron_society.jpg|thumb|Pigeon breeds on display (1864)]] Pigeon fanciers from many different countries exhibit their birds at local, inter-state or national shows and compete against one another for prizes.<ref name="Levi"/> One typical country show in Australia in 2008 had hundreds of pigeons on display and prizes for the winners.<ref>{{cite web |title=Bird lovers flock to pigeon show |publisher=Wauchope Gazette |url=http://wauchope.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/bird-lovers-flock-to-pigeon-show/766654.aspx |format=Web article |accessdate=2008-05-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Y0O3m0Im?url=http://wauchope.yourguide.com.au/news/local/news/general/bird-lovers-flock-to-pigeon-show/766654.aspx |archivedate=May 22, 2008 |df= }}</ref> In England, the Philoperisteron Society conducted annual shows in the mid 1800s. There were also a London Columbarian Society. The extensive variations in the breeds attracted the attention of [[Charles Darwin]] and played a major role in developing ideas on evolution.<ref>http://darwinspigeons.com</ref><ref>Secord, James A. (1981) Nature's Fancy: Charles Darwin and the Breeding of Pigeons Isis 72(262):162-186.</ref>
Some fanciers organize exhibitions exclusively for pigeons; one held in [[Blackpool]] run by the [[Royal Pigeon Racing Association]] is annually attended by about 25,000 people and generates around £80,000 profit, which is donated to charity.<ref>{{cite web |title=Fanciers flock to fund foundation |publisher=Bebden Bridge Times |url=http://www.hebdenbridgetimes.co.uk/sport/Fanciers-flock-to-fund-foundation.4014301.jp |format=Web article |accessdate=2008-05-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5Y3PAk3Ra?url=http://www.hebdenbridgetimes.co.uk/sport/Fanciers-flock-to-fund-foundation.4014301.jp |archivedate=2008-05-24 |df= }}</ref> <!--*''archived link for Blackpool show if needed: https://www.webcitation.org/5Y3PAk3Ra?url=http://www.hebdenbridgetimes.co.uk/sport/Fanciers-flock-to-fund-foundation.4014301.jp ''-->
The largest pigeon show is held in [[Nuremberg]]: the German National Pigeon Show, which had over 33,500 pigeons at the 2006 show.<ref>{{Cite news| last =Child | first =Brad | title ="Pigeon Pals Tour" Part II | newspaper =Purebred Pigeon (March/April 2007) | pages =71, 72. | year =2007 | date = | url =http://www.purebredpigeon.com/| postscript =<!--None--> }}.</ref>
In the United States, there are hundreds of local, state and national pigeon clubs that sponsor shows. The largest shows are the National Young Bird Show, held in [[Louisville, Kentucky]] in October, and the National Pigeon Association's Grand National, held in a different city each year and usually in January.
==Major breed families== This grouping system is adapted from ''Australian Fancy Pigeons National Book of Standards''.<ref name="Seymour">Seymour, Rev. Colin (Ed)(2006) ''Australian Fancy Pigeons National Book of Standards''.</ref> Consideration was given to the new UK standards book which followed the German and European grouping. This version differs slightly from that of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20130415154727/http://www.entente-ee.com/deutsch/sparten/tauben/Dateien/2012/ELRT%2011-06-2012.pdf European grouping]; the following system is arbitrary and used solely for organizing breed articles until a grouping can be accepted worldwide.
===Asian feather and voice pigeons=== [[File:Fantail(silver barred).jpg|right|thumb|150px|A Fantail attempting to make itself appear larger]] This group includes breeds developed for extensive feathering that originated in the [[Asia|Asian region]], as well as breeds cultivated for their trumpeting, or laughing, voice. * [[Fantail (pigeon)|Fantail]] * [[Frillback]] * [[Jacobin (pigeon)|Jacobin]] * [[Lahore (pigeon)|Lahore]] * [[Trumpeter (pigeon)|Trumpeter]] * English Trumpeter
===Colour pigeons=== [[File:Danish suabien(black - sortsvaber).jpg|right|thumb|150px|Danish Suabian]] Most of these pigeons originate in Germany, and are sometimes listed as German Toys. There are many different varieties, with a wide selection of colours and markings. * [[Archangel (pigeon)|Archangel]] * [[Danish Suabian]] * [[Saxon Field Pigeon]] * [[Starling (pigeon)|Starling]] * [[Saxon Fairy Swallow|Swallow]] * [[Thuringen Field Pigeon]] * [[Ice Pigeon]]
===Frills and Owls=== [[File:African owl(black self).jpg|thumb|right|150px|An African Owl]] The word "frill" here relates to the reversed feathering on the chest of these varieties. This group is also noted for having short beaks. * [[Aachen Lacquer Shield Owl]] * [[African Owl]] * [[Chinese Owl]] * [[Italian Owl]] * [[Old German Owl]] * [[Oriental Frill]] * [[Turbit]]
===Homer and Hen Pigeons=== ====Homing pigeons==== [[File:German Beauty Homer.jpg|right|thumb|150px|German Beauty Homer]] This group includes breeds originally developed for their homing ability, and includes show-type [[Racing Homer|racing pigeons]]. * [[American Show Racer]] * [[Dragoon (pigeon)|Dragoon]] * [[English Carrier]] * [[German Beauty Homer]] * [[Homing pigeon]]
===Pouters and Croppers=== [[File:Pigmy pouter(blue bar).jpg|right|thumb|150px|A Pigmy Pouter]] This group includes breeds developed for the ability to inflate their crops. * [[English Pouter]] * [[Brunner Pouter]] * [[Gaditano Pouter]] * [[Holle Cropper]] * Horseman Pouter * [[Norwich Cropper]] * [[Pigmy Pouter]] * [[Pouter]] * [[Voorburg shield cropper]] * Old German Croppers
===Exhibition Tumblers=== [[File:Crested helmet pigeon.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Crested Helmet]] This group originally consisted of flying/tumbler breeds, but has now been refined to include only purely ornamental/exhibition breeds. * [[Budapest Short-faced Tumbler]] * [[English Long-faced Tumbler]] * [[English Short-faced Tumbler]] * [[Helmet (pigeon)|Helmet]] * [[English Magpie]] * [[Nun (pigeon)|Nun]]
===Flying Tumblers and Highfliers=== {{main|Flying/Sporting pigeons}} [[File:Tippler.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Tippler (Light print)]] This group is dual purpose in that its members can be shown, but also retain acrobatic or sporting ability and can therefore be used in flying competitions. Flying tumbler varieties belong in this group. Although many varieties in this grouping have become primarily show varieties, they are still expected to display characteristics of performing birds.<ref name="Seymour"/> * [[Armenian Tumbler]] * [[Australian Performing Tumbler]] * [[Danzig Highflyer]] * [[Donek]] * [[Roller (pigeon)|Roller]] * [[Tippler]]
===Utility pigeons=== {{main|Utility pigeon}} [[File:Carneau.jpg|right|thumb|150px|A red Carneau]] This group includes breeds originally developed as sources of [[Squab (food)|meat]]. * [[Carneau]] * [[French Mondain]] * [[King (pigeon)|King]] * [[American Giant Runt|Runt]] * [[Strasser (pigeon)|Strasser]]
==See also== {{commons category|Fancy pigeons}} * [[Domestic pigeon]] * [[Homing pigeon]] * [[List of pigeon breeds]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.npausa.com National Pigeon Association - USA] * [http://www.purebredpigeon.com Purebred Pigeon Magazine] * [http://www.nationalyoungbirdshow.com National Young Bird Show - USA] * [http://www.incendiaryimage.com/projects/portraits-of-egypts-fancy-pigeons/ Fancy Pigeon Portraits] * [http://www.EgyptSwifts Egypt Swifts - Pigeon News]
[[Category:Aviculture]] [[Category:Columba (genus)]] [[Category:Domesticated animals]] [[Category:Domestic pigeons]]

revision.text:
{{speciesbox | status = EN | status_system = iucn3.1 | status_ref ={{IUCN2008|assessor=D'elia, G.|assessor2=Teta, P.|last-assessor-amp=yes|year=2008|id=4652|title=Chinchilla lanigera|downloaded=5 January 2009}} | image = Chinchilla lanigera1.jpg | genus = Chinchilla | species = lanigera | authority = Bennett, 1829 | range_map = Chinchilla lanigera.svg | range_map_caption= Past range of Chinchilla lanigera. | synonyms = ''Mus laniger''
''Chinchilla velligera''
''Cricetus chinchilla''
''Lommus lanigera''
''Cricetus lanigera'' }} The '''long-tailed chinchilla''' (''Chinchilla lanigera''), also called the '''Chilean''', '''coastal''', '''common chinchilla''', or '''lesser chinchilla''', is one of two species of [[rodent]]s from the genus ''[[Chinchilla]]'', the other species being ''[[Chinchilla chinchilla]]''.{{MSW3 Hystricognathi | id = 13400134 | page = 1550}} Wild populations of ''C. lanigera'' occur in Aucó, near Illapel, IV Región, [[Chile]] (31°38’S, 71°06’W), in [[Reserva Nacional Las Chinchillas]] and in La Higuera, about {{convert|100|km|abbr=on}} north of Coquimbo (29°33’S, 71°04’W){{Citation | last = Jiménez | first = J.E. | title = The extirpation and current status of wild chinchillas (''Chinchilla lanigera'' and ''C. brevicaudata'') | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 77 | pages = 1–6 | year = 1996 | doi = 10.1016/0006-3207(95)00116-6}} Chilean chinchillas were reported from Talca (35°30’S), Chile, reaching north to [[Peru]]{{cite journal|title=On the Chinchillidae, a family of herbivorous Rodentia, and on a new genus referrible [sic] to it|journal=Transactions of the Zoological Society of London|year=1835|first=E.T.|last=Bennett|volume=1|issue=|pages=35–64|doi=10.1111/j.1096-3642.1835.tb00602.x}} and eastward from Chilean coastal hills throughout low mountains. By the mid-19th century, Chilean chinchillas were not found south of the [[Choapa River]]. No [[fossil]]s are known. == Characteristics == [[File:TurboHome.jpg|thumb|left|180px|A domesticated long-tailed chinchilla]] ''Chinchilla lanigera'' is smaller (wild animals have body lengths up to {{convert|260|mm|abbr=on}}), has more rounded ears, ({{convert|45|mm|abbr=on}} in length), and longer tails than ''C. chinchilla''; its tail is usually about a third the size of its body (up to {{convert|130|mm|abbr=on}} compared to {{convert|100|mm|abbr=on}} in ''C. chinchilla''). The number of [[caudal vertebrae]] is 23 in ''C. lanigera'', and 20 in ''C. chinchilla''). Males typically weigh {{convert|369|–|493|g|abbr=on}} (mean: {{convert|412|g|abbr=on}}) and females weigh {{convert|379|-|450|g|abbr=on}} (mean: {{convert|422|g|abbr=on}}).{{cite journal|title=Chinchilla laniger|journal=Mammalian Species|date=15 December 2004|first=Angel E.|last=Spotorno|author2=Zuleta, C.A. |author3=Valladares, J.P. |author4=Deane, A.L. |author5=Jiménez, J.E. |volume=758|issue=|pages=1–9|doi=10.1644/758}} [http://www.science.smith.edu/departments/Biology/VHAYSSEN/msi/pdf/758_Chinchilla_laniger.pdf PDF] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205060715/http://www.science.smith.edu/departments/Biology/VHAYSSEN/msi/pdf/758_Chinchilla_laniger.pdf |date=2010-12-05 }} Domesticated animals are larger than wild ones and more [[sexual dimorphism|sexually dimorphic]], with the female weighing up to {{convert|800|g|abbr=on}} and males up to {{convert|600|g|abbr=on}}. The word ''lanigera'' translates into "bearing a woolen coat", yet chinchillas do not have a woolen coat, but instead one consisting of hair. Their hair is {{convert|2|–|4|cm|abbr=on}} long, with gray, white, and black bands; it is silky, extremely soft, and firmly adhered to the skin. Up to 75 hairs, {{convert|5|–|11|mm|abbr=on}} in diameter, emerge together from a single hair follicle. [[Vibrissa]]e (whiskers) are abundant, strong, long ({{convert|100|–|130|mm|abbr=on}}), and emerge from single [[hair follicle|follicles]].{{cite journal|title=Histology of the skin and hair of the adult chinchilla|journal=Anatomical Record|year=1950|first=H. N.|last=Wilcox|volume=108|issue=|pages=385–397|pmid=14799877 |url=|accessdate=|doi=10.1002/ar.1091080304}} The general color of their upper parts is bluish or silvery gray; the underparts are yellowish-white. The tail has long, coarse, gray and black hairs on its dorsal surface, {{convert|30|–|40|mm|abbr=on}} long near the body, {{convert|50|–|60|mm|abbr=on}} long near the tip, and form a bristly tuft that exceeds vertebrae by {{convert|50|mm|abbr=on}} In the wild, they breed between October and December, which are the spring months in the [[Southern Hemisphere]]. Its [[karyotype]] has [[Diploid|2n]] = 64 and [[Fundamental number|FN]] = 126. == Varieties == Three different types of ''C. lanigera'' are commonly recognized: ''la plata, costina'', and ''raton''.{{Cite book|first=Edmund|last=Bickel|title=Chinchilla Handbook|publisher=T.F.H. Publications, Inc.|place=Neptune City, NJ|year=1987|isbn=0-86622-494-7}} The ''la plata'' type has better-developed musculature and heavier bone structure than the other two types. The typical ''la plata'' looks more roundish or compact, with a short, wide head, a large distance from one ear to another, and a relatively straight dorsal line. The shoulders are often as wide as the chest and rump. The ears are short and nearly round. [[File:Chinchilla lanigera reared.jpg|left|thumb|Chinchilla ''costina'' standing on its hind legs]] The ''costina'' type is weaker in musculature and bone structure, with the most distinctive feature being the longer hind legs. The fore legs are shorter and placed closer together, and the shoulders are narrower. The vertebral column is more arched; the neck line is sometimes very deep, forming a slight hump on the back of the animal. When viewed directly from the front, the head is V-shaped, the nose is pointed, and the distance between the ears is rather wide. The ears are long and positioned at an angle around 45°. The ''raton'' type is reminiscent of the ''la plata'' type in its body structure. The nose is pointed as in the ''costina'', and the ears are positioned very close together and rather horizontal; it is distinctively smaller, on average. == Ecology == [[Image:RunningChin.jpg|left|thumb|Running chinchilla]] Climate in the chinchillas' habitat is rather harsh, with summer temperatures climbing during the day to up to 30 °C in the shade and dropping to 7 °C at night (or below the freezing point in winter). == Pelt industry == {{main|Chinchilla#Fur industry}} == Conservation status == The Chilean chinchilla is [[endangered]], with the second-highest conservation priority among Chilean mammals.{{Cite journal | last1 = Cofré | first1 = H. | last2=Marquet| first2=P.A.| title = Conservation status, rarity, and geographic priorities for conservation of Chilean mammals: an assessment| journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 88| pages = 53–68 | year = 1999 | doi = 10.1016/S0006-3207(98)00090-1}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{Chinchillidae nav}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q834053}} [[Category:Chinchilla]] [[Category:Mammals of Chile]] [[Category:Mammals of the Andes]] [[Category:Domesticated animals]] [[Category:Mammals described in 1829]]

{{distinguish|pack hunter}} {{redirect|Beast of burden|other uses|Beast of Burden (disambiguation)}}
[[File:Pack Horse 2.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3<!--size for lead image-->|[[Packhorse|Horse packing]] with traditional Australian [[pack saddle]]]]
A '''pack animal''' or '''beast of burden''' is an individual or type of [[working animal]] used by [[human]]s as means of [[transport]]ing materials by attaching them so their weight bears on the [[animal]]'s back, in contrast to draft animals which pull loads but do not carry them.
Traditional pack animals are diverse including [[camel]]s, [[pack goat|goat]]s, [[domestic yak|yak]]s, [[reindeer]], [[water buffalo]]es, and [[llama]]s as well as the more familiar pack animals like [[packhorse|horse]]s, [[donkey]]s and [[mule]]s.
==Pack versus draft==
The term ''pack animal'' is traditionally used in contrast to ''draft animal'', which is a [[working animal]] that typically pulls a load behind itself (such as a [[plow]], a cart, a [[sled]] or a heavy log) rather than carrying cargo directly on its back.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Right to be Outside: Three Mules |url=http://www.notechmagazine.com/category/pack-animals |publisher=No Tech Magazine |date=24 September 2013}}</ref> For instance, [[sled dog]]s pull loads but do not normally carry them, while working elephants have been used for centuries to haul logs out of forests.<ref>{{cite web |title=Elephants in Logging Operations in Sri Lanka |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/v9570e/v9570e02.htm |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]] |accessdate=31 January 2016 |archiveurl=http://www.fao.org/docrep/v9570e/v9570e02.htm |archivedate=7 August 2013}}</ref>
==Diversity== Traditional pack animals include [[ungulates]] such as [[camel]]s,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Best Invention Since The Wheel |url=http://www.notechmagazine.com/category/pack-animals |publisher=No Tech Magazine |date=4 January 2012}}</ref> the [[domestic yak]], [[reindeer]], [[pack goat|goats]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Pack Goats |url=http://www.notechmagazine.com/category/pack-animals |publisher=No Tech Magazine |date=13 December 2011}}</ref> [[water buffalo]]es and [[llama]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Llamas as Pack Animals|url=http://www.llamapack.com/text/packanimals.html|publisher=Buckhorn Llama Co|accessdate=26 January 2016 |date=1997}}</ref> and domesticated members of the [[Equidae|horse family]] including [[packhorse|horse]]s, [[donkey]]s, and [[mule]]s.<ref name=DonkeySanctuary>{{cite web |title=Pack-animal welfare checks introduced for the expeditions industry |url=http://www.thedonkeysanctuary.org.uk/blog/pack-animal-welfare-checks |publisher=The Donkey Sanctuary |accessdate=26 January 2016 |date=26 February 2015}}</ref> Occasionally, [[Dog hiking#Dog backpacks|dogs]] can be used to carry small loads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pets.webmd.com/features/dog-gear?page=2|title=Gear for Your Dog: Backpacks, Saddle Bags, Harnesses, and More|work=WebMD|accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://themodernbark.petgiftsonline.com/2014/07/5-best-dog-backpacks-reviewed.html |title=The Modern Bark - Dog Training Tips: Find Your Ideal Dog Backpack - 5 Best Dog Backpacks Reviewed |author=Barbara Fitzgerald |publisher= |accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref>
<gallery mode=nolines widths=150px> File:Eylcamel.jpg|A [[nomad]]'s pack [[camel]] in [[Eyl]], [[Somalia]] File:Reindeer and pack, with Lapp driver.jpg|Pack [[reindeer]] with [[Sami people|Sami]] driver from ''The land of the midnight sun<!-- : summer journeys through Sweden, Norway, Lapland and Northern Finland-->'', c. 1881 File:Fleischextrakt 0002773 m.jpg|1900 advertisement showing pack [[yak]]s in [[Tibet]] File:Lloyd the Llama.jpg|Pack [[llama]], Rocky Mountain National Park, Colorado File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Bimanees met lastkarbouwen Res. Timor Soembawa TMnr 10013888.jpg|Pack [[domestic buffalo|water buffalo]], [[Sumbawa]], Indonesia, early 20th century File:Pack donkeys, Bucks Mills, Devon.jpg|Pack donkeys, [[Devon]], England, c. 1906 </gallery>
==Uses== [[File:Hortus Deliciarum 40-3m.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Middle Ages|Medieval]] pack horse and donkey in ''Hortus Deliciarum'', Europe, 12th century, when packing was a major means of transport of goods]] [[File:Marines train resupply techniques with pack animals 140831-M-ED261-010.jpg|thumb| [[US Marines]] training in resupply with pack mules. [[Bridgeport, California]], 2014]]
Hauling of goods in wagons with horses and oxen gradually displaced the use of packhorses, which had been important until the [[Middle Ages]], by the sixteenth century.<ref name="Aston2006">{{cite book |last=Aston |first=T. H. |title=Landlords, Peasants and Politics in Medieval England |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BW2iS9JAZm4C&pg=PA55 |date=2 November 2006 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-03127-1 |pages=54–55}}</ref>
Pack animals may be fitted with [[pack saddle]]s and may also carry [[saddlebag]]s.<ref>{{cite web |title=How Much Weight Can My Horse Carry? |url=https://www.outfitterssupply.com/russon/how-much-weight.asp |publisher=Outfitters Supply |accessdate=26 January 2016}}</ref>
While traditional usage of pack animals by nomadic tribespeople is declining, a new market is growing in the tourist expeditions industry in regions such as the [[High Atlas]] mountains of Morocco, allowing visitors the comfort of [[backpacking with animals]].<ref name=DonkeySanctuary/> The use of pack animals "is considered a valid means of viewing and experiencing" some [[National Park]]s in America, subject to guidelines and closed areas.<ref>{{cite web |title=Horse & Pack Animal Use |url=http://www.nps.gov/care/planyourvisit/horsepack.htm |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=26 January 2016}}</ref>
In the 21st century, [[special forces]] have received guidance on the use of horses, mules, llamas, camels, dogs, and elephants as pack animals.<ref>{{cite web |title=FM 3-05.213 (FM 31-27) Special Forces Use of Pack Animals |url=https://fas.org/irp/doddir/army/fm3-05-213.pdf |publisher=Headquarters, Department of the Army |accessdate=26 January 2016 |date=June 2004}}</ref>
==Load carrying capacity==
The load for oxen is their body weight (1500-2500 pounds) at walking pace and 2X for short hauls. <ref>https://www.lancasterfarming.com/news/northern_edition/oxen-no-has-beens-when-it-comes-to-hard-pulling/article_b79a5f8f-5d4b-578d-997a-f385095dc7c9.html</ref>
The maximum load for a camel is roughly 300 kg.<ref>{{cite book |last1=CSIRO |title=Model Code of Practice for the Welfare of Animals The Camel (Camelus dromedarius) |date=2006 |publisher=CSIRO Publishing |page=8 |edition=2nd |url=http://www.publish.csiro.au/Books/download.cfm?ID=5204}}</ref>
Yaks are loaded differently according to region. In Sichuan, 75 kg is carried for 30 km in 6 hours. In Qinghai, at 4100 m altitude, packs of up to 300 kg are routinely carried, while up to 390 kg is carried by the heaviest steers for short periods.<ref>{{cite web|title=Draught performance|url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/006/ad347e/ad347e0g.htm|publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]]|accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref>
Llamas can carry roughly 1/4 of their body weight, so an adult male of 200 kg can carry some 50 kg.<ref>{{cite web |title=Frequently Asked Questions about Llamas and Alpacas |url=http://www.touchtheearthranch.com/llamaFAQ.htm |publisher=Touch the Heart Ranch |accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref>
Loads for equids are disputed. The US Army specifies a maximum of 20 percent of body weight for mules walking up to 20 miles a day in mountains, giving a load of up to about 150 kg. However an 1867 text mentioned a load of up to 800 pounds (about 360 kg). In India, the prevention of cruelty rules (1965) limit mules to 200 kg and ponies to 70 kg.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bonner |first1=Laurie |title=How Much Weight Can Your Horse Safely Carry? |url=http://equusmagazine.com/article/weight_carry_062608 |publisher=Equus Magazine |accessdate=31 January 2016}}</ref>
Reindeer can carry up to 40 kg for a prolonged period in mountains.<ref name="Nickul1997">{{cite book |last=Nickul|first=Karl |title=The Lappish Nation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fjwc3OoDdV4C&pg=PA29 |year=1997 |publisher=Psychology Press |isbn=978-0-7007-0922-9 |page=29}}</ref>
==Pack animals by region==
* [[Arctic]] - [[reindeer]], [[sled dog]] * [[Central Africa]] and [[South Africa]] - [[ox]], [[mule]], [[donkey]] * [[Central Asia]] - [[Bactrian camel]], [[yak]], [[mule]], [[donkey]] * [[Eurasia ]]- [[donkey]], [[ox]], [[horse]], [[mule]] * [[North America]] - [[horse]], [[mule]], [[donkey]] * [[North Africa]] and [[Middle East]] - [[dromedary camel]], [[horse]], [[donkey]], [[mule]], [[ox]] * [[Oceania]] - [[donkey]], [[horse]], [[dromedary camel]], [[mule]], [[ox]] * [[South America]] - [[llama]], [[donkey]], [[mule]] * [[South Asia|South]] and [[South East Asia]] - [[domestic buffalo|water buffalo]], [[yak]], [[Asian elephant]]
==See also==
* [[Pack station]]
==References== {{reflist|28em}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://watch.opb.org/video/2310114342 Llama Backpacking] Documentary produced by [[Oregon Public Broadcasting]]
{{Living things in culture}}
[[Category:Pack animals| ]] [[Category:Domesticated animals]] [[Category:Animal-powered transport]] [[Category:Military animals]]

'''Self-domestication''' is the process of adaptation of wild animals to humans, without direct human selective breeding of the animals. The biological processes in the evolution of humans and human culture are also referred to by the term "self-domestication".
==In animals== Wild animals may ''self-domesticate'' when tame behaviour enhances their survival in the vicinity of human beings. Tolerating or even enjoying the close proximity of humans in order to feed near them, and a lessening of natural adult aggression, are two aspects of tameness. An environment that supports the survival of tame animals can lead to other changes in behaviour and appearance as well.
Smaller skulls on tame animals have been noticed in other species. Noticing that a dog's skull looks like that of a juvenile wolf, [[Richard Wrangham]] goes on to say that "this leads to the thought that species can self-domesticate."<ref name="Wrangham" /> Other characteristics that are associated with juvenility such as barking and meowing (sounds used by wolf cubs and kittens of large felines, respectively, to communicate with their parents), increased playfulness and reduced aggression, may also be seen in tame animals.
===Cats=== Self-domestication is described by biological anthropologist [[Richard Wrangham]] as being in an environment where lessening of aggression was beneficial for survival.<ref name="Wrangham">{{cite book |title=The New Humanists: Science at the Edge |editor1-first=John |editor1-last=Brockman |chapter=The Evolution of Cooking |chapterurl={{Google books|Fb0EGAq5UmcC|page=99|plainurl=yes}} |first1=Richard |last1=Wrangham |pages=99–110 |publisher=Sterling Publishing |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-7607-4529-8 }}</ref> As grain plants and livestock became domesticated 9,000 years ago in the [[Fertile Crescent]], wild [[cat]]s adapted to living with humans, hunting rodents in grain stores and "abandoning their aggressive wild-born behaviors", which led to today's house cats.<ref name="SciencemagNEO">{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/science.1139518 |pmid=17600185 |title=The Near Eastern Origin of Cat Domestication |journal=Science |volume=317 |issue=5837 |pages=519–23 |year=2007 |last1=Driscoll |first1=C. A. |last2=Menotti-Raymond |first2=M. |last3=Roca |first3=A. L. |last4=Hupe |first4=K. |last5=Johnson |first5=W. E. |last6=Geffen |first6=E. |last7=Harley |first7=E. H. |last8=Delibes |first8=M. |last9=Pontier |first9=D. |last10=Kitchener |first10=A. C. |last11=Yamaguchi |first11=N. |last12=O'Brien |first12=S. J. |last13=MacDonald |first13=D. W. |bibcode=2007Sci...317..519D |pmc=5612713}}</ref>
===Dogs=== {{Main|Origin of the domestic dog}} While humans may have intentionally domesticated [[Wolf|wolves]] into [[dog]]s, an alternate hypothesis is that wolves effectively domesticated themselves by establishing a [[Mutualism (biology)|mutually beneficial]] relationship with prehistoric humans. They scavenged on the remains of the prey animals left by the prehistoric people at the human settlements or the kill sites. Those wolves that were less anxious and aggressive thrived, continued to follow the prehistoric humans, and colonized the human-dominated environments, generation after generation. Gradually, the first primitive dogs emerged from this group.<ref name=crockford2000>{{cite book|author=Crockford, S.|editor=Crockford, S.|year=2000|title=A commentary on dog evolution: Regional variation, breed development and hybridization with wolves| pages=11–20|publisher=Archaeopress BAR International Series 889|isbn=978-1841710891}}</ref><ref name=coppinger2001>{{cite book|author=Coppinger, R.|year=2001|title=Dogs: A Startling New Understanding of Canine Origin, Behavior & Evolution|isbn=0684855305}}{{pn|date=March 2017}}</ref><ref name=russell2012>{{cite book|author=Russell, N.|year=2012|title=Social Zooarchaeology: Humans and Animals in Prehistory| publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-14311-0}}{{pn|date=March 2017}}</ref>
===Foxes=== Research done beginning in 1959 by the Soviet geneticist [[Dmitry Belyayev (zoologist)|Dmitry Belyayev]] on [[Tame Silver Fox|silver foxes]] [[selective breeding|selectively bred]] only for tameness revealed that a whole range of other physical and behavioural features, such as [[neoteny]], also appeared along with the tameness, characteristics that were not specifically the result of selective breeding by humans. White spots on their fur, floppy ears, rolled tails and smaller skulls were seen in the tame foxes, and the foxes were also described as "incredibly endearing."<ref name=rats>{{cite web|last=Wade|first=Nicholas|title=Nice Rats, Nasty Rats: Maybe It’s All in the Genes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/25/health/25rats.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=25 February 2015|date=25 July 2006}}</ref>
Belyayev and his successors also [[selective breeding|selectively bred]] wild rats for tameness, with similar results.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/25/health/25rats.html?pagewanted=print Nice Rats, Nasty Rats: Maybe It’s All in the Genes] by [[Nicholas Wade]], [[New York Times]], 25 July 2006.</ref> These results with [[selective breeding]] suggest that the [[natural selection|natural process]] of self-domestication of animals can occur within a single human generation.
===Primates=== It has been argued that [[Bonobo|bonobos]] (''Pan paniscus''), relatives of the chimpanzee, have undergone self-domestication.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2011.12.007 |title=The self-domestication hypothesis: Evolution of bonobo psychology is due to selection against aggression |journal=Animal Behaviour |volume=83 |issue=3 |pages=573–85 |year=2012 |last1=Hare |first1=Brian |last2=Wobber |first2=Victoria |last3=Wrangham |first3=Richard }}</ref>
==In humans== Self-domestication theories describe how humans developed and evolved. The idea of self-domestication was used by early [[Social Darwinism]] which, according to psychiatrist Martin Brüne in an article "On human self-domestication",<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1747-5341-2-21 |pmid=17919321 |pmc=2082022 |title=On human self-domestication, psychiatry, and eugenics |journal=Philosophy, Ethics, and Humanities in Medicine |volume=2 |pages=21 |year=2007 |last1=Brüne |first1=Martin }}</ref> developed from the idea that humans could perfect themselves biologically.
"Contemporary reproductive technologies such as selective abortion and [[genetic screening]] are typical examples where our self-domestication is most directly apparent," writes philosopher [[Masahiro Morioka]], who also says that "Through domesticating ourselves like cattle, people began civilization."<ref>''Painless Civilization: A Philosophical Critique of Desire'' by [[Masahiro Morioka]], Transview Publications, Tokyo, 2003, {{ISBN|4-901510-18-5}}, {{ISBN|978-4-901510-18-9}} (in Japanese); translation by Kenny Gundle and Masahiro Morioka on website http://www.lifestudies.org/painless01.html, accessed 28 Oct 2008</ref>
[[Gregory Stock]], director of the [[UCLA School of Medicine]]'s Program of Medicine, Technology and Society, describes self-domestication as a process which "... mirrors our domestication [of animals] ... we have transformed ourselves through a similar process of self-selection ... our transformation has been primarily cultural, but it has almost certainly had a biological component."<ref>{{cite book |title=Redesigning Humans: Our Inevitable Genetic Future |first=Gregory |last=Stock |authorlink=Gregory Stock |pages=243–244 |location= |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin]] |year=2002 |isbn=0-618-06026-X }}</ref>
Clark & Henneberg argue that during the earliest stages of human evolution a more [[paedomorphic]] skull arose through self-domestication.<ref name="Clark & Henneberg 2015">{{cite journal |doi=10.1515/anre-2015-0009 |title=The life history of Ardipithecus ramidus: A heterochronic model of sexual and social maturation |journal=Anthropological Review |volume=78 |issue=2 |year=2015 |last1=Clark |first1=Gary |last2=Henneberg |first2=Maciej }}</ref><ref name="Clark & Henneberg 2017">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.jchb.2017.03.001 |title=Ardipithecus ramidus and the evolution of language and singing: An early origin for hominin vocal capability |journal=HOMO - Journal of Comparative Human Biology |year=2017 |last1=Clark |first1=Gary |last2=Henneberg |first2=Maciej |volume=68 |pages=101–121}}</ref> This assertion is based upon a comparison of the skull of [[Ardipithecus]] and chimpanzees of various ages. It was found that [[Ardipithecus ]] clustered with the infant and juvenile species. The consequent lack of a pubertal growth spurt in males of the species and the consequent growth of aggressive canine armoury was taken as evidence that [[Ardipithecus ]] evolved its paedomorphic skull through self domestication. As the authors state, comparing the species with [[Bonobos]]:
Of course ''A.ramidus'' differs significantly from bonobos, bonobos having retained a functional canine honing complex. However,the fact that A.ramidus shares with bonobos reduced sexual dimorphism, and a more paedomorphic form relative to chimpanzees, suggests that the developmental and social adaptations evident in bonobos may be of assistance in future reconstructions of early hominin social and sexual psychology. In fact the trend towards increased maternal care, female mate selection and self-domestication may have been stronger and more refined in ''A.ramidus'' than what we see in bonobos.<ref name="Clark & Henneberg 2015"/>
Further research has confirmed that [[Ardipithecus]] possessed paedomorphic cranial base angulation, position of the foramen magnum as well as vocal tract dimensions. This was interpreted as not only evidence of a change in social behavior but also a potentially early emergence of hominin vocal capability. If this thesis is correct then not only human social behavior but also language ability originally evolved through paedomorphic skull morphogenesis via the process of self-domestication.<ref name="Clark & Henneberg 2017"/>
The most comprehensive case for human self-domestication has been proposed for the changes that account for the much later transition from robust humans such as Neanderthals or Denisovans to anatomically modern humans. Occurring between 40,000 and 25,000 years ago, this rapid neotenization has been explained as the result of cultural selection of mating partners<ref name="Bednarik">Bednarik, Robert G. (2008). "The Domestication of Humans". Anthropologie. 46 (1): 1-17.</ref> on the basis of variables lacking evolutionary benefits, such as perceived attractiveness, facial symmetry, youth, specific body ratios, skin tone or hair, none of which play any role in any other animal species. This unintentional auto-domestication, coinciding with the introduction of imagery of female sexuality, occurred simultaneously in four continents then occupied by hominins. It led to rapid changes typical for domestication, such as in cranial morphology, skeletal architecture, reduction in brain volume, to playful and exploratory behavior, and the establishment of thousands of deleterious conditions, syndromes, disorders and illnesses presumed absent in robust humans.<ref>Bednarik, Robert G. (2011). The Human Condition. Springer, New York, pp. 127-141. {{ISBN|978-1-4419-9352-6}}.</ref> This hypothesis effectively replaces the Replacement Hypothesis (known as "African Eve theory") and explains the relatively rapid transition as a culturally induced domestication process still continuing today. It also explains the rise of exograms and their role in selecting for competence in the use of external memory traces.
==See also== * [[Domestication]] * [[Landrace]] * [[Ethology]] * [[Sociobiology]] * [[Evolutionary psychology]]

revision.text:
Some strains of animals, such as [[Deaf white cat|white cat]]s, have a tendency to [[congenital deafness]].<ref name=Suga>{{Cite journal|pmid=5411826|year=1970|author1=Suga|first1=F|title=Physiological and histopathological correlates of hereditary deafness in animals|journal=The Laryngoscope|volume=80|issue=1|pages=81–104|last2=Hattler|first2=K. W.|doi=10.1288/00005537-197001000-00007}}</ref> It is also not an uncommon problem for purebred dogs.<ref name=Wilkes1>{{cite web | last = Wilkes | first = Gary | title = Why the Deaf Dog Barks| url= http://www.clickandtreat.com/dfogb5.htm| accessdate = 2008-12-31 }}</ref> Some known chemicals and elements can also affect deafness in animals.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1007/BF00316933 |title=Ototoxic effect of nitromin and some congenital deaf animal cochlea. An electron microscopical study |journal=Archiv für klinische und experimentelle Ohren- Nasen- und Kehlkopfheilkunde |volume=198 |issue=3 |pages=325 |year=1971 |last1=Nakai |first1=Yoshiaki |last2=Nakai |first2=Sumiko }}</ref>
Deafness can occur in almost any breed of cat or dog. This includes both pure-breed and mixed-breed animals although there may be more prevalence in some specific breeds.<ref>Strain, G. M. (2010, October 5). DEAFNESS IN DOGS & CATS [Reference Site]. Retrieved October 10, 2010, from Louisiana State University website: http://www.lsu.edu/deafness/deaf.htm</ref> "The association between patterns of pigmentation and deafness in the dog has a long-documented history, with reports dating back over one hundred years. Long suspected of having a genetic basis, the search for loci with a pronounced influence in the expression of hearing loss in the dog has yet to be successful." <ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1186/1746-6148-3-31|pmid=17999773|pmc=2194672|title=Heritability and complex segregation analysis of deafness in Jack Russell Terriers|journal=BMC Veterinary Research|volume=3|pages=31|year=2007|last1=Famula|first1=Thomas R|last2=Cargill|first2=Edward J|last3=Strain|first3=George M}}</ref> Deafness in animals can occur as either unilateral (one ear affected) or bilateral (both ears affected). This occurrence of either type of deafness seems to be relatively the same in both mixed-breed animals and pure-breed animals.<ref>{{Cite journal|pmid=19192155|year=2009|author1=Cvejic|first1=D|title=Unilateral and bilateral congenital sensorineural deafness in client-owned pure-breed white cats|journal=Journal of Veterinary Internal Medicine|volume=23|issue=2|pages=392–5|last2=Steinberg|first2=T. A.|last3=Kent|first3=M. S.|last4=Fischer|first4=A|doi=10.1111/j.1939-1676.2008.0262.x}}</ref> Research as tired a significant association between deafness in dogs and the pigment genes piebald and merle. Although merle dogs seem to have higher occurrences of both deafnesses than some other breeds, this research also showed that they had lower occurrences than others. So still there is more to be known about the causes of deafness in animals such as dogs.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=19192156|year=2009|author1=Strain|first1=G. M.|title=Prevalence of deafness in dogs heterozygous or homozygous for the merle allele|journal=Journal of Veterinary Internal Medicine|volume=23|issue=2|pages=282–6|last2=Clark|first2=L. A.|last3=Wahl|first3=J. M.|last4=Turner|first4=A. E.|last5=Murphy|first5=K. E.|doi=10.1111/j.1939-1676.2008.0257.x}}</ref> Common misconceptions may lead potential owners to believe that deaf dogs may be more likely to have an unpleasant disposition, or that the condition implies other brain abnormalities. Many people have successfully raised and trained deaf animals. Teaching a deaf dog may present unusual challenges, but inventiveness can overcome many of them.
For example, deaf dogs, when out on a walk, a laser pointer could be used to attract the animals attention.<ref name=Wilkes1 />
==See also== *[[Congenital sensorineural deafness in cats]] *[[Deafness]] in humans *[[Mechanosensation]]

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2009}} [[File:Gallery 19 68 148247.jpg|thumb|right|Golden Base type flowerhorn]] {{Portal|Aquarium Fish}} '''Flowerhorn [[cichlid]]s''' are ornamental [[aquarium]] fish noted for their vivid colors and the distinctively shaped heads for which they are named. Their head protuberance, or ''kok'', is formally termed a "[[nuchal lines|nuchal]] hump." Like [[blood parrot cichlid]]s, they are [[Cichlid#Hybrids and selective breeding|man-made hybrids]] that exist in the wild only because of their [[Fishkeeping#Invasive species|release]]. First developed in [[Malaysia]], [[Thailand]], and [[Taiwan]], they became very popular with Asian [[fishkeeping|fish hobbyists]]. They are also kept by hobbyists in the US and Europe, but their importation is banned in Australia. Some cichlid hobbyists{{who|date=October 2015}} have questioned the impact of flowerhorn breeding programs and their impact on the health and reproduction of the animals, and on natural fish species.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}
== Origin ==
Flowerhorn breeding dates from 1993.<ref name=craze>[http://www.flowerhorncraze.com/Flowerhorn-101-t43104.html ''Flowerhorn 101, A Guide to Flowerhorn Strains and Types.''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312093706/http://www.flowerhorncraze.com/Flowerhorn-101-t43104.html |date=March 12, 2009 }}</ref> Malaysians admired fish with protruding heads, known as ''Kaloi'' or "warships," found in the western part of the nation. The slightly protruding forehead and long tail of these fish were prized in Taiwanese society as bringing luck in [[geomancy]]. By 1994, [[Amphilophus labiatus|red devil cichlids]] (typically ''[[Amphilophus labiatus]]'') and trimac cichlids (''[[Amphilophus trimaculatus]]'') had been imported from [[Central America]] to Malaysia and the hybrid [[blood parrot cichlid]] had been imported from Taiwan to Malaysia and bred these fish together, marking the birth of the flowerhorn.{{Dubious|date=October 2009}}
In 1995, the blood parrots were further crossbred with the ''Human Face Red God of Fortune'', which produced a new breed called the ''Five-Colors God of Fortune''.<ref name=craze/> With its beautiful colors, this fish quickly became popular. Selective breeding continued through 1998, when the ''Seven-Colors Blue Fiery Mouth'' (also known as ''Greenish Gold Tiger'') was imported from Central America, and crossbred with the ''Jin Gang Blood Parrot'' from Taiwan.<ref name=craze/> This crossbreeding led to the first generation of ''Hua Luo Han'' flowerhorn hybrids, which were then followed by subsequent flowerhorn introductions.
=== Arrival in the West ===
When ''Luo Hans'' were first imported to the United States, there were only two breeds of these fish for distribution, flowerhorn and golden base.<ref name=craze/> Flowerhorns came in two varieties, those with pearls (silver-white spots on the skin) and those without. Golden bases also had two varieties, those that faded and those that did not. Among the flowerhorns, the ones without pearls were quickly overtaken in popularity by those with pearls, becoming pearl scale flowerhorns, or ''Zhen Zhu''. With the golden bases, the unfaded ones developed an attractive golden skin in place of what had been the flowerhorn’s grey skin.
As of 1999, there were four strains of flowerhorn available in the American market: regular flowerhorns, pearl scale flowerhorns, golden flowerhorns, and faders.<ref name=craze/> Commercial breeders proliferated, and fish were selected for appearance with little regard for terminology.<ref name=craze/> Consequently, names became confusing and parentage became difficult to track.
Around 2000–2001, the ''Kamfa'' variety appeared. These were hybrids of any type of flowerhorn crossed with any species of the genus ''[[Vieja]]'' or with any parrot cichlid.<ref name=craze/> These brought in some new traits, such as short mouths, wrapped tails, sunken eyes, and increasingly larger head bumps. Seeing this, those who bred the ''Zhen Zhus'' began line breeding their fish to develop faster and become more colorful, in order to compete with the ''Kamfa'' strains.<ref name=craze/>
==In captivity== [[File:Determine flowerhorn sex.jpg|thumb|upright|Comparison of male and female flowerhorn anatomy<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.thaifh.com/flowerhorn-guides.html|title = Guides to flowerhorn sex and breeding|date = May 1, 2015|access-date = Feb 5, 2016|website = Flowerhorn guide book|publisher = www.thaifh.com|last = Thai|first = Flowerhorn}}</ref>]] Flowerhorn cichlids have a lifespan of 10–12 years. They are usually kept at a water temperature of 80–85 °F, and a [[pH]] of 7.4–8.0. They require a tank of a minimum of 55 gallons, with 125 gallons optimal. A breeding pair may require a tank of 150 gallons or more, depending on size. Being aggressive and territorial, two or more flowerhorns are usually not kept together, but the tank housing them can be divided up with acrylic dividers or egg crates.
There are several ways by which breeders distinguish between male and female flowerhorns. Generally, the males are larger than the females, but there are some exceptions. Males have the kok, or the nuchal hump, on their foreheads. Males also usually have brighter and more vivid colors. For most breeds, the females have black dots on their [[dorsal fin]]s, whereas males usually have longer anal and dorsal fins. Females tend to have an orange belly, especially when ready to breed. The mouth of the male is thicker and more pronounced than the female's. One sure way to determine the sex of flowerhorn is that grown female will lay eggs every month even without the male.<ref name="thaifh.com">{{Cite web|title = More flowerhorn guides on caring, breeding, determining sex|url = http://www.thaifh.com/flowerhorn-guides.html|website = Thai FH - Supplier of flowerhorn fish international|access-date = 2016-02-05}}</ref>
Flowerhorn cichlids are subject to several diseases, including [[head and lateral line erosion|hole-in-head disease]], [[Ichthyophthirius multifiliis|"ich"]], and digestive blockages.
== Breeds == [[File:Post-77-1231053436.gif|thumb|left|450px|General flowerhorn classification, containing several subsets of strains from different countries and breeders. The parent breed is called Luohan, from the Chinese word for the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] concept of [[arhat]]. The four main breeds of flowerhorn are Zhen Zhu, Golden Monkey, Kamfa, and Goldenbase Faders.<ref name=craze/>]]
=== King Kong Parrots and Red Ingots ===
The blood parrot was the earliest defined type of cichlid hybrid, whereas the ''King Kong'' parrot represents an early stage in the transition to flowerhorn breeding.<ref name=craze/> The blood parrot is smaller, with a bigger head, more protruding eyes, and a V-shaped mouth. The ''King Kong'' parrot is longer, with a reddish orange color, and a [[dorsal fin]] shorter than the [[anal fin]]. The shape of the ''King Kong'' is similar to the red devil cichlid, and, when it reaches a size of 18 cm, the shape of the mouth changes to a triangle with a more protruding jaw. Only 20% of these fish grow to a size of a half kilogram.<ref name=craze/>
Blood parrots and ''King Kong'' parrots are sometimes colored purple or blue by [[painted fish|pigment injection]]. This practice is unhealthy for the fish, and the color will fade with time.<ref name=craze/> Parrot cichlids fed with natural colorants and attractants naturally develop a red color. With further breeding, a round body shape has been selected, with the dorsal fin and anal fin longer than the tail fin, and the mouth can open and close naturally. These fish have clear eyes, and 90% of them grow to 1 kg or above, with the characteristic flowerhorn head shape.<ref name=craze/>
The ''Red Mommon'' and ''Red Ingot'' breeds are the most typical of these hybrid cichlids. Both of these fishes are appreciated for [[feng shui]].<ref>Arnold W (2003) Singapore's 'lucky' pet Luohan can outnumber people in homes. International Herald Tribune. July 1.</ref> The ''Red Mommon'' is named for its high forehead, which looks like the hat worn by the God of Fortune. The ''Red Ingot'' is named for its ''yuan-bao'' shape, referring to odd-shaped gold or silver pieces formerly used as money in China.<ref name=craze/>
The ''Red Mommon'' and ''Red Ingot'' grow faster in the first year, with a size of about 20 cm. They grow to 25–28 cm by two years later. Their maximum size is not yet known, and it is believed that the fish may grow to 30 cm or above in the future. Both of these fish are raised at 28 °C water temperature, pH ~6–8 (with slightly acid water preferred), and [[carbonate hardness|kH]] ~3–6, while avoiding any sudden change in water quality. It is also common to test regularly for [[ammonia]] and [[nitrite]]. Both of these fishes can be bred with different kinds of cichlids.<ref name=craze/>
=== Golden Monkey === [[File:Post-19-1231048027.jpg|thumb|right|274px|Golden Monkey]] The genuine ''Golden Monkey'' (also called ''Good Fortune'') or ''Kamalau'' was bred by Mr. Lam Seah and Lam Soon in Bercham, Ipoh, Malaysia. After the third generation, all of them were sold to the A-1 Aquarium in 2001. This type of flowerhorn is an original ''Luohan''-based fish and not a mixed type ''Zen Zhu'' or ''Kamfa''.<ref name=craze/>
It can be a particularly expensive flowerhorn, carrying a price tag of more than one thousand dollars. The most expensive ''Golden Monkey'' was sold for $600,000 dollars during a Malaysian exhibition in 2009.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} {{Clear}}
=== Kamfa === [[File:Post-19-1231048629.jpg|thumb|left|275px|Kamfa]] This breed originated from the ''Luohan''. Its main characteristics are white or yellow eyes (red eyes are possible but not common), a fan tail, a water-colored head bump, sunken eyes, and smaller lips than the ''Zhen Zhu''. This breed generally also has a larger and more square body than that of the ''Zhen Zhu''. Head flowers can be found on the ''Kamfa'', but not as prominently as with ''Zhen Zhus''. {{Clear}}
=== Zhen Zhu === This breed originated slightly after the ''Kamfa'', derived from the ''Luohan''. It has a rounded tail, large mouth, red protruding eyes, and a prominent head flower. ''Zhen Zhu'' means "pearl flowerhorn." This breed's strongest characteristic is pearling. Breeders often cross other types with ''Zhen Zhus'' because they breed easily and can create better pearling (flowerline) for the next generation. Weak tails can also carry over, however.<ref name=craze/>
=== Golden Base (Faders) === [[File:Gallery 19 68 148247.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Golden Base]] Faders are called by that name because during the juvenile period of life they lose their color and go completely black. As the fading process continues, the black "fades" away, leaving a more vibrant and beautiful color, usually yellow or red. They are also referred to as golden base or ''Golden Trimac''.<ref name=craze/>
'''[[cichlid#Hybrids and selective breeding|Red Texas cichlids]]''' are related to the golden base family of flowerhorns. They were originally created by breeding a [[Herichthys carpintis|green Texas cichlid]] with a ''Mammon'' or ''King Kong'' parrot, then crossing the offspring back to the parents until a consistent red color was achieved. Hobbyists consider the most important feature of the red Texas to be the color. Red Texas cichlids range in colors, and are rated as:
* Unfaded: lowest grade of red Texas. * Yellow: second lowest grade. * Orange: the majority of red Texas fall into this category. * Coral: pinkish but not quite full red. * Red: most desirable color.
The second characteristic that sets the red Texas apart is the pearling. Red Texas can vary greatly in terms of the type of pearling.<ref name=craze/>
=== King Kamfa === [[File:Kingkamfa.jpeg|thumb|237x237px|King Kamfa]] From the ''Kamfa'' family, this fish typically has white or yellow sunken eyes, although red eyes are possible but rare. Distinctive features of this breed include an intense black double flower row along the [[lateral line]], and very thick white pearling. Originating in Thailand, this breed has seen a recent rebirth in Vietnam. The body is typical of a ''Kamfa'', with a fan tail, and a longer body than some other ''Kamfas''.<ref name=craze/> King Kamfa is the most expensive flowerhorn strain.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
=== Kamfamalau === [[File:Post-19-1231048922.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Kamfamalau]] This is a cross of a ''Kamfa'' male and a ''Malau'' female. The body and face resemble a typical ''Kamfa'' (see above). The finnage and sunken eyes reflect the ''Kamfa'' genes. The main feature of a ''Kamfamalau'' is the pearling. Fins typically take on a "frosted" pearl look that is rarely found in any other breed of flowerhorn. Pearling usually crosses all the way across the head bump, another rarity in flowerhorn breeds. This breed should display the best characteristics of both ''Kamfa'' and ''Malau''.<ref name=craze/>
=== Thai Silk === The Thai Silk, also known as Titanium, is a relatively new breed. This flowerhorn breed is almost completely metallic blue, gold, or white. Its origins are unclear. A new strain of Thai silk has been developed that has a kamfa-type body and red, blue, or white eyes. It was believed to be a cross between White Tigers (Texas lineage), pure Texas cichlid and a Vieja. {{clear}}
== Strains == A strain is a more specific subset within a particular breed. Strains can get as narrowly defined as all coming from one individual parent fish. Strains can also differ by country of origin and by breeder.
=== JPG or Golden Apple === Created by Ah Soon of Malaysia, these fish are characterized by a large stocky body, as well as metallic pearling.<ref name=craze/>
=== IndoMalau === [[File:Post-137-1207905651.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Elvis strain]] These were created by the Indonesian ''Luohan'' Club (ILC), using a ''Golden Monkey'' (or ''Malau'') female and a ''Zhen Zhu'' male. The second generation was spawned from the ''Elvis'' selection and a ''Golden Monkey'' female. The strain is characterized by extensive pearling all over the body, face, and head. What distinguishes an ''IndoMalau's'' pearls from that of a ''Zhen Zhu'' or a ''King Kamfa'' is that they are extremely fine. As the fish ages, the pearls become more intricately woven and thinner. Flowerlines vary dramatically; some only have a few flower spots. Most ILC ''IndoMalaus'' will include some singular flowers on the back line or "top row." The front half of the fish, from the [[pectoral fin]]s forwards, is red. The back half is a golden gradient intensifying in color towards the tail. The body is very wide and high, a throwback to the original ''Luohan''. There is a very pronounced chin or "gobbler." The head is usually forward-protruding. The tail is fan-shaped, close to that of a ''Kamfa''. The dorsal and anal fins lack trailers, a common trait found also in ''Zhen Zhu''. The [[caudal peduncle]] is very large and pronounced in this strain <ref name=craze/>
[[File:Post-4-1216334880.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Tan King strain]]
=== Tan King === This strain was created by Mr. Tan of Vietnam, by crossing a ''Zhen Zhu'' with a ''Kamfa''. It has pearls and a flowerline like a ''King Kamfa'', but the body and fins are more closely related to the ''Zhen Zhu''. Most have protruding eyes and a more rounded tail like a ''Zhen Zhu''.<ref name=craze/>
===Strains developed in the United States=== New flowerhorn strains have been developed through breeding programs in the U.S. Although it is hard for the U.S. to compete with Asia's well established flowerhorn breeding farms, strains with unique genetics have been created. {{Clear}}
== Gallery of early flowerhorn strains ==
<gallery> Image:Coronation_Link.png|Coronation Link Image:Tornado Effect.jpg|Tornado Effect Image:Perfect Harmony.jpg|Perfect Harmony Image:Unique Track.jpg|Unique Track Image:Absolute Wonder.jpg|Absolute Wonder Image:Ancient Warship.jpg|Ancient Warship Image:Creative Measure.jpg|Creative Measure Image:Exotic Marvel.jpg|Exotic Marvel Image:Legacy.jpg|Legacy Image:Living Legend.jpg|Living Legend Image:Pacific Miracle.jpg|Pacific Miracle Image:Quantum Grace.jpg|Quantum Grace Image:Rising Rainbow.jpg|Rising Rainbow Image:Royal Degree.jpg|Royal Degree Image:Scarlet Passion.jpg|Scarlet Passion </gallery>
== Criticism == Criticism has also been made of placing flowerhorns, which are man-made fish, into fish taxa, which are reserved for the identification of species found in the wild.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} This practice can make identification of similar cichlids difficult. Breeding with pure bloodlines of cichlid species has already occurred in a number of cichlids commonly kept in the hobby, risking loss of genetic material.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
Flowerhorn breeding<ref>http://www.thaifh.com/flowerhorn-guides.html</ref> also contributes to the commercial demand for new and different fish, leading to unethical practices such as breeding for anatomical deformities, as occurred in goldfish breeding.
Flowerhorns have been criticized by cichlid hobbyists and [[environmentalism|environmentalists]] for a number of reasons. Interest in flowerhorns resulted in [[culling]] of surplus and deformed fish, some of which were dumped in the wild in Malaysia and Singapore, where they survived and disrupted riverine and pond [[ecosystem]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://library.thinkquest.org/04oct/01027/environmental.html |title=The Flowerhorn Fish - Fish Facts - Environmental Impacts |publisher=Library.thinkquest.org |date= |accessdate=2012-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=31&art_id=iol1045231471487W253&set_id=1 |title=Killer fish unleashed in Malaysia - IOL SciTech |publisher=IOL.co.za |date=2003-02-14 |accessdate=2012-07-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aquarticles.com/articles/breeding/Soodhanan_Flowerhorns.html |title=Flowerhorns alias Nightmares, by Madhu Soodhanan |publisher=Aquarticles.com |date= |accessdate=2012-07-05}}</ref> Like many other cichlids, flowerhorns are aggressive and can breed quickly, competing with and eating native fish.<ref>[http://www.ecologyasia.com/news-archives/2003/nov-03/straitstimes_031102_1.htm Monster fish] Arlina Arshad, [[The Straits Times]], November 2, 2003</ref>
Some hobbyists have questioned the impact of flowerhorn breeding programs and their impact on the natural species of the fish world. These hobbyists believe that all hybrid fish are detrimental to the aquarium hobby and will always be a topic of issue. These same hobbyists believe the creation of man-made hybrids makes it harder for other hobbyists to find and keep pure species.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
The majority or even most flowerhorn males are sterile, which means that they cannot reproduce. By far, a very small percent of a batch would result in fertile males whereas the rest of the batch is sterile. Since not every male flowerhorn is fertile, finding a best or perfect fertile flowerhorn is time consuming. That is, hobbyists have to wait until the fish is sexually mature and then pair the male with a female to see if the male is fertile. It takes up to 8 months for a male flowerhorn to be sexually mature. A recommended age for a flowerhorn male to be tested its fertility is 10 months. Note: The process of testing the male's fertility is the same as pairing and breeding fertile ones.<ref name="thaifh.com"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{Aquarium}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Flowerhorn Cichlid}} [[Category:Domesticated animals]] [[Category:Fish hybrids]] [[Category:Fishkeeping]] [[Category:Cichlidae]]

revision.text:
{{taxobox | name = Domestic goose | image = Domestic Goose.jpg | image_caption = An [[Emden goose]] | status = DOM | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[Aves]] | ordo = [[Anseriformes]] | familia = [[Anatidae]] | subfamilia = [[Anserinae]] | genus = ''[[Anser (genus)|Anser]]'' | species = '''''[[Anser anser|A. anser]]''''' & '''''[[Anser cygnoides|A. cygnoides]]''''' | subspecies = '''''A. a. domesticus''''' & '''''A. c. domesticus''''' | binomial = ''Anser anser domesticus'' & ''Anser cygnoides domesticus''
([[Robert Kerr (writer)|Kerr]], 1792) | synonyms =
''Anser domesticus'' | binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]] }} '''Domestic [[Goose|geese]]''' (''Anser anser domesticus'' or ''Anser cygnoides domesticus'') are domesticated [[grey geese]] (either [[greylag goose|greylag geese]] or [[Swan goose|swan geese]]) that are kept by [[human]]s as [[poultry]] for their meat, eggs, and [[down feathers]] since ancient times. ==Origins and characteristics== [[File:Domestic geese swimming.jpg|thumb|A pair of [[swan goose]]-type domestic geese swimming]] In [[Europe]], northern [[Africa]], and western [[Asia]], the original domesticated geese are derived from the [[greylag goose]] (''Anser anser''). In eastern Asia, the original domesticated geese are derived from the [[swan goose]] (''Anser cygnoides''); these are commonly known as '''Chinese geese'''. Both have been widely introduced in more recent times, and modern flocks in both areas (and elsewhere, such as [[Australia]] and [[North America]]) may consist of either species or [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] between them. Chinese geese may be readily distinguished from European geese by the large knob at the base of the bill, though hybrids may exhibit every degree of variation between the two species.Buckland, R., & Guy, G. (2002). ''Goose Production''. Chapter 1: [http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/005/Y4359E/y4359e03.htm Origins and Breeds of Domestic Geese]. FAO Agriculture Department. The [[domestication]], as [[Charles Darwin]] remarks (''[[The Variation of Animals and Plants under Domestication]]'' i. 287), is of very ancient date, with archaeological evidence for domesticated geese in [[Egypt]] more than 4,000 years ago.Hugo, S. (undated). [http://www.fao.org/docrep/V6200T/v6200T0n.htm Geese: the underestimated species]. FAO Agriculture Department. They are much larger, and they have been selected for that larger size, with domesticated breeds weighing up to {{convert|10|kg}}, compared to the maximum of {{convert|3.5|kg}} for the wild swan goose and {{convert|4.1|kg}} for the wild greylag goose.del Hoyo, J., Elliott, A., & Sargatal, J., eds. ''[[Handbook of Birds of the World]]'' Vol. 1: 581. Lynx Edicions, Barcelona. {{ISBN|84-87334-10-5}} This affects their body structure; whereas wild geese have a horizontal posture and slim rear end, domesticated geese lay down large fat deposits toward the tail end, giving a fat rear and forcing the bird into a more upright posture. Although their heavy weight affects their ability to fly, most breeds of domestic geese are capable of flight. Geese have also been strongly selected for [[fecundity]], with females laying up to 50 [[egg (biology)|eggs]] per year, compared to 5–12 eggs for a wild goose. As most domestic geese display little [[sexual dimorphism]], sexing is based primarily on physical characteristics and behaviour. Males are typically taller and larger than females, and have longer necks. In addition, males can be distinguished by the protective behaviour they exhibit towards their mates and their offspring - the male will typically stand between his partner and any perceived threat. Changes to the plumage are variable; many have been selected to lose dark brown tones of the wild bird. The result is an animal marked, or completely covered in white feathers. Others retain plumage close to the natural; some, such as the modern [[Toulouse goose]] look almost identical to the greylag in plumage, differing only in structure. White geese are often preferred as they look better plucked and dressed, with any small down feathers remaining being less conspicuous. From the time of the Romans, white geese have been held in great esteem. Geese produce large edible eggs, weighing {{convert|120|-|170|g}}. They can be used in cooking just like chicken's eggs, though they have proportionally more yolk, and this cooks to a slightly denser consistency. The taste is much the same as that of a chicken egg, but gamier. Like their wild ancestors, domestic geese are very protective of their offspring and other members of the flock. The gander will normally place himself between any perceived threat and his family. Owing to their highly aggressive nature, loud call and sensitivity to unusual movements, geese can contribute towards the security of a property.{{cite news |url=http://www.fao.org/docrep/V6200T/v6200T0n.htm#the_unbridable_watchdog|title=Geese, the unbridable watchdog|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|date=16 August 2014 |accessdate=16 August 2014}} In late 1950s South Vietnam, the [[VNAF]] used flocks of geese to guard their parked aircraft at night due to the noise they would make at intruders.Grandolini, A. ''Indo-Chinese Fighting ' Cats: Grumman's Superb Bearcat in Vietnam'' Air Enthusiast magazine article July-August 1997 No.70 p.17 Because domestic geese descended from the [[Greylag goose]] are effectively the same species as their wild ancestor (being a subspecies formed through domestication), escaped individuals readily breed with wild populations, resulting in the offspring sometimes resembling either one of their parents, or bearing mixed plumage with patterns of grey and white feathers. Image:Anser cygnoides (fl).jpg|Farm goose: erect posture and fat rear end Image:Anser cygnoides-Beijing.jpg|Wild goose: horizontal posture and slim rear end ==Geese in fiction and myth== [[File:Goose attack.jpg|thumb|right|Domestic geese have been used for centuries as [[Guard goose|watch animals and guards]], and are among the most aggressive of all poultry.]] [[File:MotteGeese.jpg|thumb|left|"The geese of the Capitol" by [[Henri-Paul Motte]], 1889]] When Aphrodite first came ashore she was welcomed by the [[Charites]] (Roman "Graces"), whose chariot was drawn by geese. There are [[Mother Goose]] tales, such as a farmwife might have told; there is the proverbial [[The Goose That Laid the Golden Eggs|goose that laid the golden eggs]], warning about the perils of greed. The geese in the temple of Juno on the [[Capitoline Hill]] were said by [[Livy]] to have saved [[Rome]] from the [[Gaul]]s around 390 BC when they were disturbed in a night attack.{{cite book |last1=Cocker |first1=Mark |last2=Mabey |first2=Richard |author2link=Richard Mabey |title=Birds Britannica |titlelink=Birds Britannica |date=2005 |publisher=Chatto & Windus |isbn=0-7011-6907-9 |pages=74–76}} The story may be an attempt to explain the origin of the sacred flock of geese at Rome. Liliane Bodson and Daniel Marcolungo, ''L'oie de bon aloi: Aspects de l'histoire ancienne de l'oie domestique'' [The goose in ancient life and folklore]. Vise (Musée Regional d'Archeologie et d'Histoire de Vise), 1994, discusses the image and lore of domestic geese in classical antiquity, with a separate chapter on the goose in folklore. ==See also== *[[Angel Wing]] - A disease common in geese. *[[Domestic duck]] *[[List of goose breeds]] *[[Roast goose]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Domesticated geese}} {{wikispecies-inline|Anser cygnoides chinensis}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120502162001/http://www.tumbledownfarm.com/drupal/Cyclopedia_of_American_Agriculture/Animals/III_NA_Farm_Animals/Poultry/Geese Article "Geese" in Cyclopedia of American Agriculture, Volume III, Animals (1907)] {{Poultry}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Domesticated birds]] [[Category:Geese]] [[Category:Poultry]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} This is a '''list of domesticated animal breeds originating from Scotland'''. To be considered [[domesticated]], a population of animals must have their [[Ethology|behaviour]], [[Biological life cycle|life cycle]], or [[physiology]] systemically altered as a result of being under human control for many generations.<ref name=zeder2015>{{cite journal|author=Zeder MA|year=2015|title=Core questions in domestication Research|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|volume=112|issue=11|pages=3191–8|doi=10.1073/pnas.1501711112|pmid=25713127|pmc=4371924}}</ref>
[[Scotland]] has produced some of the longest established breeds of domesticated animals still in existence. There are 37 individual breeds of animals from Scotland still in existence and three extinct breeds. The [[Soay Sheep]] has [[prehistory|prehistoric]] origins, and the [[Galloway cattle|Galloway]] breed of [[beef cattle]] dates back several hundred years. New breeds have also been developed more recently in Scotland, such as the [[Scottish Fold]] cat, which dates from 1961.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = https://www.petfinder.com/cat-breeds/Scottish-Fold|title = Scottish Fold Cat Information|date = |accessdate = 14 November 2015|website = Pet Finder|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
The [[North Ronaldsay sheep|North Ronaldsay Sheep]] is a most unusual breed, subsisting largely on a diet of [[seaweed]],<ref name=SheepCentre> {{cite web |url=http://www.sheepcentre.co.uk/sheep_breeds.htm |publisher=Seven Sisters Sheep Centre |work=Sheep Breeds |title=North Ronaldsay |accessdate= 23 April 2009}}</ref> and the [[Boreray (sheep)|Boreray]] is the UK's rarest sheep, having been listed as "Category 2: Endangered" by the [[Rare Breeds Survival Trust]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = http://www.rbst.org.uk/Our-Work/Watchlist|title = RBST Watchlist|date = |accessdate = 8 November 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Some breeds, such as the [[Shetland Pony]] and the [[Border Collie]] are well known throughout much of the [[Western world]], whilst others such as the [[Scots Dumpy]] chicken are little-known, even at home.{{Citation needed|date = November 2015}} Nine breeds of dog have Scottish origins, including five [[terrier]] breeds.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.infodogs.co.uk/dog-breeds/country/scotland|title = Dogs from Scotland|date = |accessdate = 14 November 2015|website = InfoDogs|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Indeed the relative isolation of many of [[List of Scottish islands|Scotland's numerous islands]] has led to a preponderance of breeds from these places being represented. Various breeds are now extinct, including the [[Grice]], an archaic and somewhat aggressive pig.<ref name=bbc>{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/north_east/6155172.stm | title = Extinct Island Pig Spotted Again | publisher = [[BBC News]] | date = 17 November 2006 | accessdate = 1 January 2007}}</ref>
==Extant breeds== [[File:Shetland Sheepdog and Rough Collie.jpg|thumb|A [[Shetland Sheepdog|Sheltie]] and a [[Rough Collie]] (right)]] {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width: 12em;" | Breed !Photo!!Species !!Date of Origin !!Location of Origin !!Status |- |valign="top"|[[Scottish Fold]] |[[File:White_scottishfold.jpg|frameless]] | [[Cat]] |1961 |align="center"|[[Coupar Angus]] |Rare<ref name=":1" /> |- |valign="top"| [[Angus cattle|Aberdeen Angus]] |[[File:Angus cattle 18.jpg|frameless]] |[[Cattle]] |18th century |align="center"|[[Aberdeenshire]] [[Angus, Scotland|Angus]] |Common<ref>[http://www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle/angus/ "Angus"] Oklahoma State University. Retrieved 21 July 2009.</ref> |- |valign="top"| [[Ayrshire cattle|Ayrshire Cattle]] |[[File:AyrshireCattle1.JPG|frameless|220x220px]] |Cattle |prior to 1800 |align="center"|[[Ayrshire]] |Common<ref>[http://www.ayrshirescs.org/the_breed.shtml "The Breed"] Ayrshire Cattle Society. Retrieved 20 July 2009.</ref><ref>[http://www.usayrshire.com/whyayrshire.html "Why Ayrshires"] US Ayrshire Breeders' Association. Retrieved 20 July 2009.</ref> |- |valign="top"| [[Belted Galloway]] |[[File:Belted_Galloway_at_Gretna_Green.jpg|frameless]] |Cattle |17–18th century |align="center"|[[Galloway]] |Rare<ref>[http://www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle/beltedgalloway/index.htm "Belted Galloway"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325113238/http://www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle/beltedgalloway/index.htm |date=25 March 2009 }} Oklahoma State University. Retrieved 20 July 2009.</ref> |- |valign="top"| [[Galloway cattle|Galloway]] |[[File:Galloway.jpg|frameless]] |Cattle |700–1100 |align="center"|Galloway |Established worldwide<ref>[http://www.nzgalloway.co.nz/client/galloway_history "Galloway History"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014010013/http://www.nzgalloway.co.nz/client/galloway_history |date=14 October 2008 }} Galloway Cattle Society of New Zealand. Retrieved 20 July 2009.</ref> |- |valign="top"| [[Highland Cattle]] |[[File:Highland Cattle 10.JPG|frameless]] |Cattle |Pre 19th century |align="center"|[[Scottish Highlands|West Highlands]] |Established worldwide<ref>[http://www.highlandcattlesociety.com/highland_breed/highland_breed.aspx "The Highland Breed"] Highland Cattle Society. Retrieved 20 July 2009.</ref> |- |valign="top"| [[Luing cattle|Luing Cattle]] |[[File:Luing Cattle.jpg|frameless]] |Cattle |Post 1947 |align="center"|[[Luing]] |"Firmly established"<ref>[http://www.luingcattlesociety.co.uk/public/history.php "History of the Breed"] Luing Cattle Society.
